title: Invalid bitcast error or SIGILL during compilation of portable simd mask operations

labels.name: E-needs-test
labels.description: Call for participation: writing correctness tests

body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.
-->

I updated some benchmark code using portable simd to a current nightly (which included the llvm version bump from 15 to 16) and ran into the compiler getting killed with SIGILL, or when trying to simplify the code, an LLVM error about an invalid bitcast. It is likely that the problem is inside llvm itself, but so far I was not able to reduce the code to a minimal LLVM IR example.

The initial problematic code involved `gather_select_unchecked`:

```rust
use std::simd::*;

pub unsafe fn gather_to_array(mask: u8, indices: &[u32; 8], data: &[u32]) -> [u32; 8] {
    let mut output = [0_u32; 8];
    let m = masksizex8::from_bitmask(mask);
    let i = u32x8::from_slice(indices);
    let g = u32x8::gather_select_unchecked(data, m, i.cast(), u32x8::splat(0));
    output.copy_from_slice(&g.to_array());
    output
}
```

I could later reproduce it also with casting masks between bitmask, `isize` and `i32`:

```rust
pub unsafe fn mask_to_array(mask: u8) -> [i32; 8] {
    let mut output = [0; 8];
    let m = masksizex8::from_bitmask(mask);
    output.copy_from_slice(&m.to_int().cast::<i32>().to_array());
    output
}
```

In compiler explorer, with arguments `-C opt-level=3 -Ctarget-cpu=skx` the output is the following:

```
Invalid bitcast
  %5 = bitcast <8 x i32> %4 to [8 x i32], !dbg !36
in function _ZN7example13mask_to_array17he21e4210be9ff5c1E
LLVM ERROR: Broken function found, compilation aborted!
Compiler returned: 101
```

Compiling the same function, with an added `main` function in the rust playground (in release mode) leads to the compiler receiving a SIGILL

```rust
pub fn main() {
    unsafe {
        let output = gather_to_array(0b1010101, &[0, 9999, 1, 9999, 2, 9999, 3, 9999], &[10, 20, 30, 40]);
        std::intrinsics::black_box(output);
    }
}
```

